;;唐纳德·特朗普在任期内撒谎比历史上任何一位美国总统都多。他威胁要发动核战争，称新纳粹分子是“非常优秀的人”，对流行病管理不善，并煽动国会大厦叛乱。然而，他的民意支持率仍与总统乔·拜登大致持平。谁在 11 月获胜以及以多大优势获胜，将由我所说的“双重仇恨者”决定：那些对特朗普先生和拜登先生都持怀疑态度的人。

;

;我每周与选民举行焦点小组讨论，我总是听到双重仇恨者的声音。他们往往偏向温和、受过教育、居住在郊区的人。他们在摇摆州的比例过高，尤其是宾夕法尼亚州、威斯康星州和密歇根州等关键的“蓝墙”州。政治的粗鲁和功能失调让他们感到沮丧，他们对 2024 年的感受可以用一位选民最近告诉我的话来概括：“这实际上是一个非常恶心的选择。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;大多数人感觉好像他们在两害之间做出选择。他们将一系列负面事物与拜登联系在一起，从通货膨胀、犯罪到边境混乱。与此同时，选民对特朗普失忆了。他们忘记了他在任期间每天的愤怒、发脾气、滥用权力以及弥漫在空气中的恐慌感。

;

;为了赢得选举，拜登竞选团队必须提醒选民特朗普先生不适合担任公职的独特原因。总统不必让每一个摇摆不定的选民相信他是他们的理想候选人；他只需要表现出比特朗普更好的选择即可。正如他喜欢说的：“不要将我与全能者进行比较，而将我与另一种选择进行比较。”

;

;许多选民记得的是 2020 年之前的美好时光。许多人对低利率和新冠疫情前蓬勃发展的经济有着美好的回忆。拜登应该继续强调今天的经济正在好转。选民往往是经济改善的滞后指标；许多人尚未感受到近期积极事态发展的影响，包括通胀下降和工资上涨。但他们开始转变态度。这些天，我从选民那里听到的关于美国正处于第二次大萧条的消息越来越少，更多的是关于我们如何稳步摆脱困境。这对拜登来说是个好消息。

;

;与此同时，选民认为总统已经老了——非常老了。每个焦点小组都会对他的年龄表示担忧。尽管他的年龄远非优势，但总统应该充分接受“聪明老人”的伎俩。他在三月份的国情咨文演讲中的强劲表现帮助抵消了其中一些担忧。最近，他在广告中将自己的年龄放在了首位和中心位置。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;选民对拜登副总统卡马拉·哈里斯的担忧更加棘手。我听到的关于哈里斯女士最常见的话题之一是“她在哪里？”这份工作是出了名的吃力不讨好，人们对哈里斯女士的许多抱怨与他们在担任副总统时对拜登先生的抱怨是一样的。尽管人们传统上不会根据副总统的选择进行投票，但这一次感觉更加紧迫，因为许多人预计拜登先生在完成任期之前会因健康事件而丧失能力。他弥补这一弱点的唯一方法是让选民清楚地了解特朗普所构成的危险，因为他是唯一可行的选择。

;

;由于摇摆州的许多选民表示，他们会选择两害相权取其轻，因此拜登先生的工作就是让人们明白这一想法特朗普的第二个任期意味着什么。这需要通过可靠的信息传达者来传达他们的担忧。这些信使的外表、声音、说话和行为都必须像选民一样。简而言之：这需要普通人。我的组织“反对特朗普的共和党选民”正在利用之前投票支持特朗普但拒绝在 2024 年再次投票的共和党人，并在关键摇摆州放大他们的声音。

;

;例如，宾夕法尼亚州戴夫的两分钟证言可能无法让费城郊区一位倾向保守派的母亲相信拜登先生实际上是一位伟大的总统。但这可能足以让她相信，特朗普再执政四年是不可接受的。与此同时，如果那些在他手下任职的最高层人士——迈克·彭斯、詹姆斯·马蒂斯、约翰·凯利和尼基·黑利等亲眼目睹了混乱的人——能够站出来说话，也会有所帮助。如果不是拜登先生，那么至少是反对特朗普先生。

;

;特朗普内阁中许多最资深、最受尊敬的前成员认为他不适合担任总统；包括他的前国家安全顾问约翰·博尔顿和他的前国防部长马克·埃斯珀在内的一些人甚至发誓不会投票给他。向记者公开是一回事，接触广大选民则完全是另一回事。它需要组织、广告和数百万美元才能接触到最重要的选民。

;

;如果这些前官员真的相信特朗普先生是特别危险的，那么逻辑表明他们支持唯一能够阻止他参与政治事务的人。白宫，即使他们不同意他的一些政策或希望他更年轻。

;

;此时此刻，拜登先生看起来像是失败者。但这就是活动的目的。他和他的团队有时间扭转局面。特朗普先生和他的运动在 2020 年失败（以及 2018 年和 2022 年中期选举）。这次的胜利之路贯穿了那些对两位候选人都持怀疑态度但仍愿意被其中一位候选人说服的人们。

;

;2020 年，特朗普被一个广泛的联盟击败，其中包括从进步的民主党人到有原则的共和党人等所有人。与其说这是一个支持拜登的联盟，不如说是一个反特朗普的联盟。如果拜登先生想在 11 月获胜，它必须再次重组。;■;

;;A; ;十年前;有人意识到保护互联网大片区域安全的锁不起作用。 Open;SSL; 是一种用于加密从社交媒体密码到电子商务购买的任何内容的工具，它有一个致命的缺陷，使得潜在的黑客可以看到它应该保护的信息。对于任何了解 Open;SSL; 背后团队的人来说，这一发现并不令人意外。该软件被近 20% 的网站使用，其中包括年利润数十亿美元的科技公司，主要由两个名叫史蒂夫的人运营，他们在业余时间开发该软件。对代码的评论包含了对潜在弱点的承认，例如“EEK！实验代码开始。”

;

;在该缺陷之后，该缺陷被称为“;Heartbleed;”被发现，科技公司承诺投入数百万美元扩大 Open;SSL; 团队。爱好者将成为受薪员工，能够更好地保护网络安全。但上个月，互联网基础设施中的另一个漏洞被发现：一名志愿者在两年内帮助运行 ;XZ; Utils，这是一款用于在 Linux 上压缩和解压缩数据的软件，Linux 是一种用于关键技术的操作系统。互联网基础设施的一部分，有;将恶意软件走私到代码中;，允许黑客发送本来可以被阻止的恶意命令。一个志愿者运行的项目再次遭到破坏——这一次是故意的。 2021 年，记录计算机错误的工具 Log4j 也面临类似的漏洞。鉴于这些违规行为发生的频率，为什么有这么多关键软件由业余爱好者维护？

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;历史学家 Mar Hicks 表示，这在一定程度上是历史的一个怪癖弗吉尼亚大学技术博士。互联网自诞生以来一直是去中心化的：企业与学者和爱好者共享控制权。英国国家网络安全中心（防御性机构）前首席执行官夏兰·马丁 (Ciaran Martin) 补充道，这始终涉及国家和企业利益之间的不稳定休战，国家和企业利益为互联网的启动项目提供了资金，志愿者爱好者则维护了大部分技术。该国信号情报机构;GCHQ;。修补匠和爱好者构成了开源运动的重要组成部分，这是一个由互联网用户组成的社区，他们开发免费使用的软件并将底层代码公开。此类软件;普遍部署;在互联网的大部分地区由于成本低廉，因此可以节省基础设施的成本。

;

;虽然一个人可以维护一个小型软件项目，但当技术被广泛采用时，压力就会增加。生活——包括有偿工作——可能会成为障碍。爱好者可能会感到无聊。或者更糟糕的是：负责维护 ;XZ ;Utils 的开发人员 Lasse Collin 在最近的违规事件发生前两年警告说，维护该系统正在损害他的心理健康。

;

;这会对所有互联网用户造成危险。网络安全公司 Synopsys 分析了 17 个行业的软件，发现其审查的代码中有四分之三存在弱点，这些弱点要么已被证明会使其容易受到攻击，要么之前已被黑客利用。这令人担忧，但很难纠正。马丁先生表示，支撑我们数字世界的基础设施嵌入得太深，无法拆除和重建以适应其用途。他认为，任何一家公司这样做都没有商业动机。开源安全基金会 (Open;SSF;) 的 Omkhar Arasaratnam 是《心脏出血事件》之后利用大型科技资金建立的项目的继承者，他表示，科技行业希望建造更多的摩天大楼，但离开了向志愿者提供管道和污水处理设施。

;

;如果科技公司不自己建造更好的基础设施，仍然有办法提高互联网安全：向 Open;SSF; 等组织支付足够的费用来雇佣其他人来做这件事。但要实现这一目标，科技公司需要联合起来（如有必要，在政府的推动下）提供持续的资金，而不是在出现问题时大肆挥霍，并在注意力消退时忘记问题。; ■;

;; T ; ;红色;现代共产主义中国的贵族行为与中世纪西方世界的蓝血管贵族的行为非常相似。这个精英群体以其世袭血统而著称：它包括与毛泽东并肩作战的革命者的后裔，以及1949年共产党接管中国后统治中国的人的后代。由于他们的社会地位很高，这些红色贵族——有时被称为“红色贵族” “太子党”——在中国社会的各个方面都享有特权和影响力。他们对自己身份的认识有时会灌输一种高尚的义务。

;

;这是一个极为独特的群体，而且它的原型将是中国共产党秘书长（; CCP ;）和该国总统习近平。 As a son of Xi Zhongxun, a member of Mao's ruling cadre, Mr Xi was segregated from normal society at birth: he was most likely born in the special ward of a hospital in Beijing reserved for ;CCP; aristocrats.他在一个为党内高级人物保留的封闭大院里长大。 He was admitted to Tsinghua University not on merit but because of who he was.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Xi started his political career as secretary to a leader in the Central Military Commission, a对于尚未展示才能和能力的人来说，高度选择性的位置。由于他的血统，他继续被中央党组织部门修饰，并通过; ccp ;的排名稳步上升。 “权力必须交给我们的孩子； 1989 年天安门大屠杀后，前副总理陈云对邓小平说道：“如果不，我们的坟墓以后就会被挖掉。” 30 年跨度内每三年一次。对于正常同志，每五年的晋升将被视为好运。

;

;在XI先生上升至; ccp ;的最终领导角色，红色贵族氏族是他最强大的支持基础。 However, the relationship became complicated after he assumed power in 2012, and with his subsequent efforts to solidify his control.

;

;In the past, there在著名的红色家庭中，人们一直在不知不觉中分享。这使得一些人能够对省份施加强大的政治影响，另一些人能够对主要行业施加强大的政治影响，而少数人则能够对两者都施加强大的政治影响。例如，叶剑英家族“拥有”广东、王震家族“控制”新疆、李鹏家族锁定电力产业，这在中国社会某些阶层是众所周知的。 This oligopolistic arrangement reaped astronomical financial profits for some families.

;

;Mr Xi innately views the other prominent families as potential threats to his dictatorial rule. Certainly, you can argue that only the red clan, with its resources and bloodline entitlement, could mount a fight strong enough to topple him.

;
;

; dealt severely with members of the clan who have shown opposition or voiced criticism of him—among them Bo Xilai, a former Politburo member and party secretary in Chongqing, whose political ambition led to his imprisonment;国有地产公司前负责人任志强因公开批评习近平，称他是“不穿衣服的小丑”，被判处 18 年徒刑。 XI先生还“鼓励”其他红色贵族从他们在人民解放军中的高级领导角色退休。

;

;中国有很长的历史of emperors playing off bureaucrats from the peasantry against those from the hereditary aristocracy.习近平的做法也没有什么不同。 To further strengthen his control and continue loosening the red aristocracy's long-term hold on political power, he has consistently elevated bureaucrats from outside the red bloodlines to the ;CCP;'s central power functions.看看中共最高领导机构——政治局常务委员会的七名成员的组成，其中没有一个现任成员可以被视为具有红色贵族血统。 This has never happened before.

;

;In addition to the loss of political prerogative, red aristocrats have suffered significant economic losses under Mr Xi. As China's major wealth-owners, red aristocrats have shouldered a disproportionate share of the heavy losses suffered by Chinese stocks in recent years.

;

;The wealth accumulated by the red families in recent decades, both onshore and offshore, is an important part of their power.如果在中国情况不顺利，海外财富也是他们的保险。 How Mr Xi chooses to handle those riches—and the extent to which he is prepared to confiscate them in order to keep the clan compliant—is, therefore, of paramount importance to the red aristocrats.

;

;Confiscation of wealth as a way to bring down politically powerful or financially influential figures has been used throughout Chinese history—including by the ;CCP; since it took power in 1949. Mr Xi has already targeted several red billionaires.最近的一个典型例子是安邦保险集团创始人、邓小平的孙女吴小晖的垮台。 2018年，他被判处18年徒刑，并剥夺了他在公司创立的全部股份。

;

;

;The red aristocrats' web of influence, stretching across the bureaucracy, the armed forces and business, has been spun over the seven decades since the ;CCP; took over China.他们继续享有专有特权，包括参加政治主题集会的权利，并且仍然是一个有凝聚力和影响力的群体。但他们对权力的控制已经被他们自己的人放松了。经过习近平的“反腐”运动十年的权力集中之后，宗族势力已不足以对他构成严重的政治威胁。 Their heyday is over.;■;

;;A;< small>;S SOON AS; the volunteers appear, those that have been waiting for them on Kyiv's central Independence Square (known as Maidan) form a queue, shuffle forward and take a warm drink and a freshly cooked meal.一位老人试图平息他患有精神障碍的成年儿子的吵闹。战争使数百万人陷入经济困境，但在全面入侵开始两年后，一些人遭受的苦难比其他人要严重得多。 The hardest hit are the elderly, the disabled and the displaced.

;

;In 2023 ;Ukraine's; ;GDP; was 72% of what it was in 2021. Millions have either lost their jobs, or had their pay cut by struggling employers.但在任何远离前线的大城市里走一走，今天你几乎不会知道那里正在发生战争。上个月，一家新开的大型书店距离罗马慈善机构圣艾智德的志愿者分发食物的地方只有几分钟的步行路程。 Shops, businesses, cafés and restaurants are packed and plenty of people are driving fancy cars.

;;
;

;;Read more of our recent coverage of the ;Ukraine war;;

;
;

;However, ;the war; has tipped many into poverty, especially those who were hard-pressed before, and above all those whose homes and livelihoods have been lost.世界银行去年 11 月的一项调查发现，9% 的乌克兰人在过去 30 天内的某个时候曾耗尽食物。 3月份，根据基辅智库经济战略中心的数据，23%的人处于粮食不安全状态。 Some 14% were unemployed.

;

;Yevhen Hlibovytsky, an analyst, says some caution is needed when interpreting such data. The war has indeed caused “a lot of poverty”, 他说。 But Ukrainian society is less “atomised” than its Western counterparts. Family safety-nets help to a greater extent than in the West.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That is certainly true. But lining up for food on Maidan are the unlucky ones. Many of the pensioners there say that, far from getting help from their children, they are begging them for money. Some of those in need spend their days travelling around Kyiv picking up help from different humanitarian organisations. After food, utilities, medicines and communal housing charges they all say they have nothing left.这是有充分理由的。 In 2022 inflation hit 26.6% and in 2023 it was still 5.1%. Although pensions have increased, the increments have varied and have not kept pace with inflation. Pensioners have all seen their incomes severely eroded. Average monthly pensions are the equivalent of $135.

;

;More than a quarter of the population, 10.5m people, are pensioners. But they are far from the only ones to have lost out, says Oksana Zholnovych, the minister for social policy. So have the 3m who receive a disability benefit. Their number has increased by 300,000 in two years, thanks to wounded soldiers, injured civilians and people who have had other issues ranging from heart attacks to war-related stress issues.

;

;Many of the volunteers on Maidan initially came to Sant'Egido because, having fled from fighting or Russian occupation, they needed help themselves. There are 3.7m internally displaced people (;IDP;s) in Ukraine. On her phone Natasha shows a satellite image of a ruined apartment block in the eastern city of Bakhmut, which fell to the Russians in May 2023 after almost a year of heavy fighting. “My home,” she says. In Bakhmut she was a kindergarten teacher, and her family all had their own homes. She had extra income from renting out two other properties. Now she says, her friends and family are either unemployed or work at jobs in supermarkets for which they are very overqualified. “It was a comfortable life,” she says. “Now I live off humanitarian aid.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Although many do get aid, their mainstay has been social security. Until March 1;st; some 2.5m ;IDP;s received a monthly payment (of $77 for those with children or disabilities and $51 for others) , which could be topped up with other help 。 Anyone deemed capable of working is now ineligible to receive this ;IDP; payment, and the number of recipients is expected to drop to about 1.5m.

;

;In this time of war, pensions and social-security payments have a far greater significance than just cash in the bank, says Ms Zholnovych. When everyone got their money in March 2022, the first disbursement after the beginning of the full-scale invasion, it was hugely symbolic. Those payments meant then, and still mean she says, that “we are fighting, we are holding on, the state exists.” Ukraine's allies have understood this. The budget for all of Ukraine's social payments, except for pensions, is now being financed with their money.

;

;For 2024 Ukraine needs $37.3bn of external financing and there is likely to be a shortfall.这将意味着社会支出的削减，或许还意味着能源价格的上涨，而能源价格未能跟上通货膨胀的步伐。 Hlib Vyshlinsky, who heads the Centre for Economic Strategy, says he thinks that 2024 will be just about “manageable”. What worries him is how to keep going in the years to come if the war continues “and we do not have foreign support.” Grinding Ukrainians down on the front and impoverishing them behind it, so that they lose the will to fight on, is clearly part of Vladmir Putin's plan. ;■;

;;T;;he hedge; < small>;fund's; branding is a clue. 1789 Capital was set up last year and named for the year ;Congress ;proposed America's bill of rights.它为投资者提供了将资金投入其所说的三个关键主题的机会：平行的保守经济，迎合那些希望避免受到自由主义思想轰炸的消费者；远离自由贸易； and firms that have been penalised by the environment, social and governance (;ESG;) investment trend. Its founder, Omeed Malik, a former banker, has hosted fundraisers for ;Robert Kennedy junior;, an anti-vaccination, long-shot presidential candidate.

;

;1789 Capital is part of an increasingly important trend: American politics is infecting investing.民主党人和共和党人对世界的看法出现了分歧。许多美国人希望通过任何可能的方式表达他们的政治身份；其他人则将金钱视为影响商业行为的一种方式。所有这些都在影响投资决策。 The amount of money invested in, say, novelty exchange-traded funds (;ETF;s), such as those tracking the portfolios of certain politicians, is small, but other developments are more significant. Some $13bn has been withdrawn from BlackRock's accounts, for instance, as red states boycott asset managers that support ;ESG;. A bitterly fought rematch between Donald Trump and Joe Biden will most likely supercharge the trend.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;According to a forthcoming paper by Elena Pikulina of the University of British Columbia and co-authors, the portfolios of Democrat and Republican retail investors began to diverge half-way through Barack Obama's presidency, before consistently widening.通过将投资顾问的数据与县级选举结果相结合，研究人员发现，倾向共和党的县的投资者会避开首席执行官向民主党捐款的公司的股票，而倾向民主党的县的投资者则不太可能投资这些公司的股票。当人们担心公司对待工人的待遇时。 Voters also indirectly influence decisions made by their political representatives, as can be seen with the ;ESG ;boycotts.

;

;What motivates this behaviour?一种可能性是，民主党和共和党只是对经济发展方向以及哪些投资表现最佳存在分歧。根据这种解读，这种分歧不是投资者试图实现政治成果的结果，而是政治世界观的产物。事实上，圣路易斯华盛顿大学的 Maarten Meeuwis 及其同事发表的一篇论文发现，美国投资者的风险偏好会根据谁入主白宫而变化。 2016 年总统大选后，一些倾向民主党的投资者出售股票并购买债券，这表明他们对未来感到担忧。共和党人却反其道而行之。 Although only a relatively small number of people made such moves, those who did typically shifted more than a quarter of their holdings.

;

;The authors argue this reflects differing interpretations of economic data.毕竟，这反映了民主党和共和党在消费者信心方面的分歧。当总统来自自己的政党时，两人对经济更有信心，控制通货膨胀和失业。密歇根大学的一项消费者信心调查发现，政治方面存在显着差异——比年龄或收入方面的差异更大。 During Mr Biden's time in office, Republicans have on average expected 2.4 percentage points more inflation in the year ahead than Democrats.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yet different world views do not entirely explain the trend 。党派人士似乎也在购买股票以表达支持，就像他们张贴候选人的海报一样。 Truth Social, Mr Trump's social-media holding firm, surged when it listed on the Nasdaq in March, as supporters rushed to buy the stock. 2016 年特朗普获胜后，倾向于民主党的县的投资者加大了对清洁能源公司的投资，尽管结果对此类企业来说可能是个坏消息。 To these investors, returns matter less than identification with the cause, says Stephen Siegel of the University of Washington, one of Ms Pikulina's co-authors.

;

;Partisan investors also hope to change business behaviour. Since red states began to pull money from BlackRock, the firm's boss, Larry Fink, has begun to shy away from referring to ;esg;.其他著名的资产管理者和银行家也是如此。与此同时，南加州大学的马修·卡恩（Matthew Kahn）及其同事进行的一项研究发现，当美国各州的养老基金变得更加向民主党靠拢时（例如，当新州长上任时），其投资的公司会更快地减少碳排放.

;

;Partisan investing is both problem and opportunity for financiers. The rise of ;ESG ;investing at first allowed asset managers to distinguish themselves from rivals. 2021 年，约有 1200 亿美元流入此类基金。但在 2023 年最后一个季度，它们首次出现净流出。现在的困难是既要向双方推销产品又不惹恼任何一方——随着新话题的加入，这项任务变得越来越困难。 10 月，佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯 (Ron DeSantis) 给金融数据公司晨星可持续发展公司 (Morningstar Sustainalytics) 90 天的时间，要求其“澄清其商业行为，或停止抵制以色列”。 He argued that its ;ESG ;metrics classified companies as a risk for having invested in Israel.晨星公司委托撰写的一份独立报告建议，为在“占领区”运营的公司取消特定标签——该公司打算遵循这一建议。 Florida has since removed Morningstar from the warning list.

;

;It is not just conservatives making a fuss.资产管理公司先锋集团因退出行业机构“净零资产管理公司倡议”而成为激进分子的目标。 In January the Sunrise Project, a campaign group, began running advertisements in Pennsylvania, the firm's home state, accusing it of giving in to bullies.

;

;At the same time, smaller firms can indulge partisans.长期以来，一直有一些基金在投资决策中采用自由主义视角，例如 1984 年成立的 Parnassus Investments。右翼基金也加入了它们的行列。 As well as 1789 Capital, there is Strive Asset Management, set up in 2022 by Vivek Ramaswamy, an ertswhile Republican presidential candidate, which offers investors an American energy ;etf; that focuses on fossil fuels and has the ticker ;DRLL;.

;

;Taking a stand can be expensive. Researchers at the Federal Reserve and the University of Pennsylvania have found that anti-;ESG; boycotts raised the cost of borrowing for Texan municipalities by $300m-500m as banks with ;ESG ;policies withdrew from underwriting bond sales. 2016 年特朗普获胜后，民主党人纷纷抛售股票，他们可能会在大选后的反弹中失利。 In the year after the vote, the ;S;&;P; 500 rose by 21%.

;

;Markets thrive on differences of opinion: every seller needs a buyer and every buyer needs a seller.为投资者提供表达这些观点的机会的基金不一定是坏事。但美国资本主义是建立在不惜一切代价追求利润的基础上的。近几十年来，投资者纷纷涌向追踪市场、提供多元化且费用低廉的指数基金。 To the extent that partisan investors are trying to reshape the economy to align with their values, rather than betting on beliefs about the economy, they are going to pay for it. ;■;

;;J;;UST ONE WEEK; ago, hope looked fanciful. President Joe Biden's pitch to spend $100bn on aid for America's allies under threat—Israel, Taiwan and especially Ukraine—had ;languished in Congress; for six months since it was proposed in October 2023. The dithering had consequences. Ukrainian soldiers, forced to ration ammunition, are being pummelled by Russians with an artillery advantage of five to one.  America's senior general in Europe warned that they would soon be outgunned by a margin of ten to one. Bill Burns, the ;CIA; director, warned on April 18th that, without any more aid, “there is a very real risk that the Ukrainians could lose on the battlefield by the end of 2024.”

;

;The man needed to see the necessary national-security budget bill through, Mike Johnson, the Republican speaker of the House, seemed unfit for the task.六个月前，在他的大声、孤立主义的同事们对他们的前任领导人凯文·麦卡锡进行了攻击后，约翰逊从相对默默无闻的角色中脱颖而出，缺乏领导经验。他在议会中只拥有微弱的多数席位，多次投票反对乌克兰为自己提供资金，如果他改变主意，他将面临自己一方的弑君威胁。几个月来，他似乎陷入了瘫痪，优柔寡断。 And yet on April 20th, under Mr Johnson's leadership, the House of Representatives met the moment, passing the budget bill through extraordinary parliamentary manoeuvring with large, bipartisan majorities in defiance of the isolationist faction of the Republican Party.尽管约翰逊所在政党的大多数成员投票反对对乌克兰提供额外援助，但约翰逊在民主党的一致支持下确保了该法案的通过。 The isolationists managed to delay America's support for its allies for six months, but ultimately could not defeat it.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Johnson's courage— what even his Democratic opponents have described as his Churchillian moment, may have come about for three reasons. First, Mr Johnson became haunted by the briefings he received as one of the congressional leaders in the Gang of Eight, who can receive highly classified intelligence. “I really do believe the intel and the briefings that we've gotten,” he said in recent remarks to the press. “I believe that Xi [Jinping] and Vladimir Putin and Iran really are an axis of evil.”

;

;Second, Mr Johnson seemed to realise that his turn in power was destined to be brief, regardless of his actions. Marjorie Taylor Greene, an irrepressibly isolationist Republican congresswoman who seems to believe that Mr Putin is fighting on the side of Christianity against Ukraine, filed a “motion to vacate” (or sack) Mr Johnson after he passed a bill to keep the federal government open with Democratic votes. The speaker could have laboured in fear of such a threat or, as he daringly did, strike a bargain with Democrats to support him in exchange for bringing up the foreign-aid bill.

;

;Third, Mr Johnson may have cleverly secured the tacit blessing of ;Donald Trump; by paying a flattering visit to Mar-a-Lago last weekend. It did not hurt that one of Mr Trump's ideas, of labelling economic aid to Ukraine's government as a loan instead of a grant, was incorporated. Rather than urge his fellow Republicans to vote against the bill, Mr Trump only griped that Ukraine's survival “should be much more important to Europe than to us but it is also important to us!”

;

;The House was the last significant hurdle. Chuck Schumer, the Democratic Senate majority leader, expects to hold a vote on the combined package on Tuesday. Because the Senate overwhelmingly passed a very similar aid package in late February, it should do so again. Mr Biden is certain to sign it into law.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The consequences for Ukraine will be nearly immediate, preventing serious setbacks on the battlefield in the near term and undercutting Russia's long-term belief that its war economy—it is devoting at least 6% of ;GDP; to defence—is an unstoppable juggernaut. America is planning to send $61bn to Ukraine in total. The vast majority of that will be spent on lethal aid by replenishing American military stockpiles, allowing more to be given away, and procuring new weapons and ammunition from American arms firms. The first priority is desperately needed shells. An American three-star general has already been assigned the job of organising arms deliveries, subject to the vote. The Pentagon should be able to start getting shells to Ukraine within two weeks, reckons Michael Kofman of the Carnegie Endowment, a think-tank, and can supply enough to last for a year or so. Larger weapons systems will take much longer to ship; some still need to be ordered, let alone manufactured. The hope is that it will be enough to fend off a larger-scale Russian offensive that Kyrylo Budanov, the head of Ukraine's military-intelligence service, has said he expects in June.

;

;Ukraine has other looming problems, though. Its stock of air-defence interceptor missiles, fired from a mix of American, European and Soviet-era launchers, has dwindled. Russian attack jets have recently been providing close air support to troops with seemingly little risk of being shot down. America's Patriot missile-defence systems are in high demand elsewhere, including Israel, and production is low. At the same time, Russia is deploying effective new weapons. On April 11th it successfully launched an attack on a thermal power station in Kyiv using a Kh-69 stealth cruise missile that eluded a Patriot interceptor. Even with enough kit, Ukraine confronts a serious manpower disadvantage compared with Russia. This month Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine's president, reduced the age for conscription to the armed forces to 25 despite the considerable unpopularity of that measure.

;

;Although the provisions for Ukraine are the most important, the other bits passed by the House are consequential, too. Progressive Democrats strenuously objected to the $16bn in military aid for Israel, because of the dire humanitarian conditions in Gaza. Much of this spending would replenish defensive weapons like those used by Israel's Iron Dome, but it also provides billions for new offensive weapons. American authorities would be given the ability to seize $5bn in Russian sovereign assets that have been frozen since the start of the war and transfer them to Ukraine to help defray the cost of defending itself. Riding along with the bill is a hotly debated law that would force the sale of TikTok, a time-sucking app, to a non-Chinese owner within the next year.

;

;Seeing all of this through will be the legacy-defining achievement of Mr Johnson. Ukraine will get the ammunition and weapons systems (including, perhaps, more long-range ;ATACMS;) that it needs to weather a Russian offensive—at least until the next president is sworn in next year. Many feared that a Trump victory would force Ukraine to accept either defeat or a huge territorial loss in 2025. Without congressional action, though, that might have happened even while Mr Biden remained president. Mr Johnson's reward for defying members of his own party is unlikely to be more power—some are already speculating that his speakership might be over within a matter of weeks. “I could make a selfish decision and do something that's different but I'm doing here what I believe to be the right thing,” he said this week. “History judges us for what we do.” ;■;

;;“A;;MERICANS CAN ALWAYS; be counted on to do the right thing…after they have exhausted all other possibilities.”没有证据表明温斯顿·丘吉尔曾经说过这句话，而这句话通常被认为是他说的。 But if he had been watching Congress on April 20th, he might well have.

;

;After months of bitter wrangling, the House of Representatives ;passed a bill; to appropriate $61bn to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia.它还通过了另外三项法案：一项是帮助以色列；一项是帮助以色列；一项是帮助以色列。一是阻止中国进攻台湾；其中一项措施包括强制将 TikTok 出售给非中国所有者。 All four bills are now expected to pass the Senate within days, and President Joe Biden will sign them.

;That it took so long to do the right thing by Ukraine was disgraceful.其陷入困境的防御者全年都严重缺乏弹药和防空拦截器。俄罗斯的入侵者一直在占领乌克兰人的职位至少为乌克兰人射击，从而获得了领土。俄罗斯导弹和无人机无情地轰炸乌克兰城市，通常采用“双击”攻击，首先攻击平民，然后攻击前来帮助受灾者的医护人员。 European powers have cobbled together stopgap supplies of materiel, but without American help, Ukraine would struggle to hold out indefinitely.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;As soon as the bill becomes law, it should quickly make a difference on the battlefield.五角大楼已预先准备好武器物资并准备交付。第一批炮弹可能会在几周内甚至更早抵达。乌克兰地面部队对他们的到来充满信心，不再像以前那样热衷于保存弹药。 The chances of a catastrophic Russian breakthrough this year have significantly receded.

;

;Many problems remain, however, both practical and political.首先会感受到实用的。乌克兰需要的一些大型装备，例如反导弹和防空电池，将需要更长的时间来建造和运输。在一段时间内，太多的导弹将穿过乌克兰的天空，太多的俄罗斯战机将在乌克兰上空自由飞行，准备支持地面部队，预计下个月将发起大规模进攻。此外，美国装备无法解决乌克兰的另一个军事限制：人力。 Fighting off a giant neighbour has taken a ;huge toll; on Ukraine's defenders. The recent lowering of the call-up age from 27 to 25 will help, but maintaining morale will require immense skill from Ukraine's political and military leaders.

;

;The political picture in America is, if anything, more complicated. Previous attempts to authorise fresh aid to Ukraine were sabotaged by Donald Trump, whose sway over Republican primary voters is such that few Republican lawmakers dare risk his wrath. A compromise bill in February, which would have combined funding for Ukraine with funding for additional security on America's southern border, thus answering a Republican complaint, ;perished; when Mr Trump dismissed it as “horrendous”. He could have derailed the current bill, too. Why didn't he?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;There are plenty of Trump supporters who have swallowed some or all of Vladimir Putin's propaganda: that Ukraine is run by Nazis, that Russia stands for Christian values and against wokery. Plenty more take the isolationist view that every dollar spent supporting a faraway war would be better spent at home, or think that Ukraine distracts America from the real threat, China.

;

;Mr Trump is sympathetic to some of these views, but less extreme than his most vocal fans. Though hardly a model of coherence or consistency, he appears to have balked at letting ;Ukraine lose;, perhaps for fear that the resulting geopolitical mess would land on his desk if he regains the presidency. He may have been swayed by a recent meeting with the Polish president, Andrzej Duda, a fellow populist but one who takes a firm line on Russia. He may also have been mollified by the fact that some of the Ukraine aid is now technically a loan, as he had suggested (albeit on terms so soft as to be hard to distinguish from a grant).

;

;It would help if more Republicans—and more Democrats—could articulate more clearly why helping Ukraine is in America's self-interest. If Mr Putin is not stopped in Ukraine, he will ;keep going;.如果美国放弃乌克兰，而成本只占五角大楼预算的一小部分，而且美国人没有流血，美国的敌人和朋友都会得出结论，山姆大叔是一个善变的保护者。中国更有可能入侵台湾。韩国和沙特阿拉伯等盟友更有可能寻求核武器，从而引发不稳定的地区军备竞赛。 The surest way for America to bolster global peace and preserve its own credibility is to stick by Ukraine.

;

;With American and European support, Ukraine should be able to hold the line.西方的国防预算正在增加，其军工厂正在扩张。俄罗斯经济规模小得多，以至于即使普京的战争优先于其他一切，从长远来看，它也无法在竞争中击败自由世界。然而，普京先生赌的是，西方的政治分歧迟早会阻碍其对受害者的支持。这场灾难本周末得以避免。但到了十一月，没有人能确定。 ;■;

;“We can't play politics on this. We have to do the right thing.”众议院议长迈克·约翰逊周三宣布，他将继续推进一项向乌克兰提供更多军事援助的法案，尽管共和党同僚警告称，他们可能会试图将他赶下台。他耸耸肩，把威胁放在一边。 “History judges us for what we do,” he said.
;
;What an encouraging sentiment, particularly coming at the same time that a former and maybe future president went on trial over charges that he paid hush money to a porn star and Gallup reported that Americans, having had among the highest confidence in their key institutions of the citizens of ;G7; nations 20 years ago, now had the lowest. 
;
;Maybe Mr Johnson, who hesitated a dangerously long time before stepping up to Ukraine's defence, will lose his nerve, or maybe that notable defendant (and social-media mogul), Donald Trump, will undercut him. But if the speaker holds firm, his act of leadership should be inspiring not only because he is facing down bullies such as Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia. It is also an encouraging demonstration of moral seriousness because he has changed his mind, and not for reasons of domestic politics.  
;
;Before becoming speaker Mr Johnson, a conservative from Louisiana with a parson's manner, was a sceptic of aid to Ukraine: he opposed bills in 2022 and 2023 to provide it.但他告诉记者，他对收到的情报简报感到震惊。 “I believe Vladimir Putin would continue to march through Europe if he were allowed,” he said.他认为，向欧洲提供援助比向欧洲派遣军队更好。 He has a son about to start at the Naval Academy, Mr Johnson noted, so for his family “this is a live-fire exercise.”
;
;Here's a third hopeful inference from Mr Johnson's stand: the resurgent isolationist impulse has not yet taken full command of the Republican Party. Mr Johnson said that support for a country like Ukraine was important not just for Americans but for free people around the world. 
;
;And a fourth: bipartisanship in the cause of common sense is not dead. Once Mr Johnson assumed the speakership he seemed anxious to curry favour with Mr Trump's base, refusing to bring a bipartisan Senate border-security bill up for a vote after Mr Trump suggested he would prefer to have the problem to campaign on.但他已经求助于民主党来通过支出法案，现在他将再次需要他们的帮助。他持有一种异端观点，认为共和党人要想取得进展就必须妥协，因为他们只控制政府的一个部门，而且几乎控制不了这个部门。 President Joe Biden said he “strongly” supports Mr Johnson's approach.
;
;Mr Johnson has taken a bill passed by the Senate with a bipartisan majority and broken it into pieces, to finance aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan.第四项法案将包括共和党的其他优先事项。他希望在周六晚上之前通过所有这些法案。无论他是否成功，他的核心小组很可能会投票罢免他的议长职务。格林女士已经朝着这个目标迈出了第一步。 But Mr Johnson said that if he operated out of fear of such threats, he would not be able to do his job properly—words that I wish leaders atop America's other beleaguered institutions would take to heart.
